article:
A 'transcript' is a written record of spoken language. In court proceedings, a
transcript is usually a record of all decisions of the judge, and the spoken
arguments by the litigants' lawyers. A related term used in the US is docket,
not a full transcript. The transcript is expected to be an exact and unedited
record of every spoken word, with each speaker indicated. Such a record was
originally made by court stenographers who used a form of shorthand abbreviation
to write as quickly as people spoke. Today most court reporters use a
specialized machine with a phonetic key system, typing a key or key combination
for every sound a person utters. Many courts worldwide have now begun to use
digital recording systems. The recordings are archived and are sent to court
reporters or transcribers only when a transcript is requested. Many
US transcripts are indexed by Deposition Source so that they may be searched by
legal professionals via the internet. Transcripts may be available publicly or
to a restricted group of persons; a fee may be charged.

Transcripts may also be produced digitally. Transcripts produced by a digital
reporter are oftentimes more accurate than those produced by a court
stenographer.
